node.title: MIQ exemptions for workers as labour shortage squeezes primary sector
node.description: The government is letting more migrant workers into the country to help with the labour shortage gripping the primary sector.

node.title: Auckland and all other 'red' regions, except Northland, moving to 'orange'
node.description: Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern has announced Auckland and all other red regions, excluding Northland, will move to Covid-19 framework setting orange at 11.59pm on Thursday 30 December.

node.title: Airport's therapy dogs to assist with busiest week in domestic travel
node.description: Christchurch Airport plans to have the country's first 'Airpawt Ambassadors' on duty for for pats, cuddles and 'paw-fives' to help ease any anxiousness.

node.title: Democratic governors to focus on local issues, not Trump, in 2022
node.description: After GOP shows strong performance in Virginia and New Jersey elections, Democrats pivot to emphasize local impact of Biden's agenda.

node.title: Tornado Survivor Finds Family Bible, His Birth Certificate Tucked Inside, in Home's Debris
node.description: Kentucky Gov. Andy Beshear said Monday the current death total for the tornado is at least 64, as recovery and search efforts continue across the state.

node.title: Columbus Zoo Barred From Species Survival and Breeding Programs After Losing Accreditation
node.description: Tom Schmid, the new president and chief executive officer of the zoo, said Monday's decision was disappointing but the zoo was "moving forward."

node.title: Australia Decides 2022: Who's in, who's out and how YOU could be in the running to represent Australia at Eurovision
node.description: The field for next year's Australia Decides is taking shape, but what do we know about the performers in the running to be Australia's 2022 Eurovision entrants, and what two names will we have to wait for? Check out our guide to the event.

node.title: House price growth 'set to continue to ease' - CoreLogic

node.title: Wellington's Frank Kitts Park restoration to be completed by late 2022
node.description: Wellington's Frank Kitts Park will have its iconic lighthouse slide brought back next year.

node.title: 89-year-old charged with ill treatment of children pleads not guilty
node.description: An 89-year-old man charged with injecting adolescent patients with a paralysing drug at Lake Alice psychiatric hospital in the 1970s has pleaded not guilty to eight charges of ill-treating children.

node.title: Covid-19: Campaign urges Kiwis to dial down abuse and hostility
node.description: Complaints flooding in to the Human Rights Commission has led to a campaign urging New Zealanders dial down the anger and hostility over Covid-19 and vaccines. Audio

node.title: First members of military are discharged for refusing COVID vaccine
node.description: The Air Force has discharged 27 service members.

node.title: U.S. Unlikely to Deliver Aircraft to Israel Before 2024, Officials Say
node.description: The Israeli request to speed up delivery of the KC-46 refueling tankers came amid new tensions between Washington and Jerusalem over how to deal with Iran’s nuclear program.

node.title: Oxford Community Schools Close After Threat Against Middle School Two Weeks After Shooting
node.description: The district stated that it was closing "out of an abundance of caution."

node.title: Dems in Race for New York AG Withdraw After Letitia James Announces Re-Election Campaign
node.description: James said she is focusing on her re-election as attorney general and that she wants to finish active investigations, including into the NRA and Donald Trump.

node.title: NT records one new COVID case in outbreak, three presumptive cases detected in remote communities
node.description: The Northern Territory has recorded one new case of COVID-19 related to the current outbreak, but authorities say three presumptive cases have been detected in remote communities.

node.title: Fonterra should be able to 'capitalise on opportunities' - minister
node.description: The Agriculture Minister says some small tweaks still need to be made to Fonterra's capital restructure but he will support the legislative change needed for it to go ahead.

node.title: Parliamentary eye-opener: an intern’s view
node.description: First Person - Despite the loud arguments in the debating chamber, the select committee meetings are peaceful and serious. The contrast between them really surprised me.

node.title: System Used by Virginia Legislature Hit With Ransomware, Complicating Upcoming Session
node.description: "Anything to do with bill drafting or bill referrals — all of that has been impacted," said Senate Clerk Susan Clarke Schaar.

node.title: Biden Is Likely to Be a Talking Point When Presidents of China and Russia Speak This Week
node.description: China and Russia remain large challengers to U.S. power, with growing threats of cyber-hackers, military escalation and Democratic oppression.

node.title: Alleged Ship Arsonist 'Disgruntled' Before Fire, Navy Says in Hearing
node.description: The fire began on July 12, 2020, in the lower storage area of an amphibious assault ship while it was docked at Naval Base San Diego, injuring over 60 people.

node.title: Newcastle COVID outbreak could become one of 'highest transmission events' in the world this year
node.description: The Argyle House nightclub COVID-19 cluster has grown to 150, after 650 people checked into an event there last Wednesday.

node.title: Billions in potential income from upgrading digital trade uptake, study finds
node.description: Research has found that if digital trade improved along NZ's supply lines, both it and its Asia-Pacific Economic Corporation trading partners could gain up to $18 billion over the next decade.

node.title: Erebus Memorial: Contractors begin work after protest disruption
node.description: Progress on the memorial was stalled earlier this year after protesters camped out Auckland's Sir Dove-Myer Robinson Park.

node.title: Rapid antigen testing: What you need to know
node.description: Explainer - The Ministry of Health is considering further rollout of rapid antigen tests to the general public. Here's what you need to know about the current rules and what experts have to say. Audio

node.title: Mt Ruapehu crater lake heats up, small earthquakes expected
node.description: GNS Science says small volcanic earthquakes can be expected a Mt Ruapehu as the Crater Lake goes through a new heating phase.

node.title: 'I probably wouldn't have been fighting for my life in ICU if I had been vaccinated'
node.description: A Hamilton mum, who says she was a Covid-19 denier until she got the virus, is finally back home after ending up in hospital. Audio

node.title: Covid-19 booster shot: Investigation after person injected with used needle
node.description: The Canterbury DHB is investigating after a person was injected with a used needle when getting a booster shot of the vaccine.

node.title: Healthcare workers reject DHB pay offer
